She said: Mr. Speaker, I am delighted and honoured to introduce for debate today private member's Bill C-279, an act to amend the Food and Drugs Act (breast prostheses).
The purpose of this bill is to ensure that people are protected from dangerous and potentially dangerous breast prostheses. Bill C-279 would have a number of direct affects on the regulation of the breast prostheses industry.
First, it would create within the current Food and Drugs Act a specific category for breast prostheses apart from other medical devices. At the moment, the only devices that receive specific mention in the regulations are contact lenses and menstrual tampons.
These two items should, of course, be carefully regulated. But it seems very strange to me that they should be uniquely singled out while breast prostheses should be lost in the catch-all grouping of "any device designed to be implanted into the tissue or body cavity of a person for 30 days or more".
If breast implants are given individual mention, hopefully Health and Welfare Canada might re-examine its policy about other implants as well, ensuring the safety of still more Canadians, and specifically Canadian women.
Second, Bill C-279 would affect all breast implants regardless of when they became available on the market. When the current regulations to the Food and Drugs Act were introduced in 1982, products that were already on the market had no obligation to meet the new safety requirements.
The government has yet to produce the necessary evidence that would demonstrate that the Meme implant was one of these. In fact, to this day, the only proof supplied by the government to back up its claim that the Meme implant was on sale in Canada before October 8, 1982 is a series of advertisements in various journals dating back to that period.
Based on this meagre evidence, there was no obligation to question the safety of the Meme and, therefore, to conduct a full safety review. I might add that because of this, the Meme implant was really on the market in Canada illegally.
The Meme implant is widely used throughout Canada and is by far the most popular implant in the province of Quebec. Plastic surgeons like the Meme because it is much easier to implant than some of the others that are on the market.
Thousands of women across Canada have received these implants and many are veiy happy with the results that this medical device has achieved. Eighty per cent of those are within the province of Quebec. However, there are also many women who have suffered tremendously because of this product.
I wonder, would these women be in the situation that they are in today had the Meme manufacturers been obligated to prove the safety of this implant. Or would the manufacturers have been forced to modify the implant so that no woman would have to go through the hell that some of the implant recipients have endured.

March 16, 1992
Private Members' Business
The third effect of Bill C-279 would be to ban absolutely the specific category of breast implants that contain a degradable ingredient such as silicone that is likely to cause the presence in the body of a substance that the Food and Drugs Act prohibits.
It seems strange that the current regulations are not sufficient to protect women from substances that are prohibited by legislation, but it is clear from the evidence presented by groups such as I knowUe sais, that they are not.
Perhaps the most important effect that Bill C-279 will have is the indirect influence it will exert on the breast prosthesis manufacturers. When they realize that the Government of Canada is finally taking this issue seriously, they will be forced to make sure that any breast implant they make for distribution in Canada will have to be unequivocally safe.
I first introduced Bill C-279 in this House almost two years ago, in June 1990. At that time, the government already had overwhelming evidence there was a problem with the regulations as they stood. One of Health and Welfare's own scientists, Dr. Pierre Blais, had spoken out about the many dangers of the Meme implant as early as 1986. Yet two years later, this government still is waffling.
For anyone who is unfamiliar with the Meme implant, it is a breast prosthesis composed of a silicon gel contained inside a polyurethane foam covering. This is the same foam that you will find inside furniture cushions, carburetors or air conditioners, except in this case it is inside women.
Rather than removing the Meme implant from the market, the Minister of National Health and Welfare chose to remove Dr. Blais from the department. Dr. Blais was forced to resign in 1989.
In May 1989, the government commissioned a review of the safety of the Meme implant. The doctor commissioned to carry out the work, Dr. Carolyn Kerrigan, was a plastic surgeon from Montreal who used the implants herself. She implanted them in her patients and benefited from the Meme's continued presence on the market. This was not a very unbiased study, was it? There is no conflict of interest here.
Her results were: "There is inadequate evidence in the experimental and clinical literature to implicate polyurethane covered implants as initiators of human cancer".
"Inadequate evidence" that they were dangerous? How about adequate evidence that they were safe? In any case, cancer is certainly not the only health risk to humans. We now know that these implants can cause a variety of diseases from arthritis to kidney failure to failure of the auto-immune system as well as a series of ailments including persistent headaches, muscular inflammation, circulation disorders, back pains and skin diseases.
Five full years after Dr. Blais' first warnings, in April 1991, the Meme was removed from the market. Last month, Dow Coming, a major American manufacturer of silicone gel implants, released evidence that it has known the dangers of silicone gel implants for over two decades. That is more than 20 years.
The mandate of Health and Welfare Canada is to protect Canadians from health hazards. It is not enough for the Minister of National Health and Welfare merely to accept the evidence it is given by the manufacturer. It does not take a rocket scientist to see the conflict of interest that is involved here.
On January 8 of this year, in response to the actions of the food and drag administration of the United States, the government asked manufacturers to stop distributing silicon gel implants in Canada. Over a month later, on February 17, an advisory committee was established to study silicone gel implants. It could be months before the study is complete.
I am glad that the government is finally acknowledging that a problem exists. Why is it taking so long? Obviously there is a problem with the legislation as well as with the process.
Even now, rather than proceeding cautiously, the government is forging ahead with plans to speed up the approval of new products. Drug reviews are being contracted out to private consultants. Many of these consultants are being paid to conduct research for the very same companies that are being investigated.
The government policy at the moment seems to be "better sorry than safe". It is not enough to have biased opinions from plastic surgeons saying there is insufficient evidence to show that a product is dangerous. Canadian
March 16, 1992

women deserve more that that. They deserve legislated protection from less scrupulous manufacturers that may want to market unsafe breast implants in the future.
Each year, over one million Canadian women discover they have breast cancer. Many of these women have resorted to reconstructive breast surgery to try to ease the trauma of the painful and humiliating disfigurement that results. For some the cure is worse than the disease. Marcella Tardif was one such survivor. She had surgery for cancer. The implants she received following her surgery caused her physical pain long after she should have fully recovered.
Ms. Tardif started a support group for women who had suffered from breast implants. She found that she was not alone. Hundreds of women had been severely harmed by these implants. They have formed a support group that is called I know//e sais. It has helped many women but the price has been very high.
Ms. Tardif has even received death threats for her attempts to get the government to do something. I myself have received a letter of threat. Obviously someone out there is very sensitive to the attention that some of us have tried to bring to this tragic issue.
It is also evident that Health and Welfare Canada is either incapable or unwilling to protect the women of Canada from unsafe medical devices. Therefore, these amendments to the Food and Drugs Act are very much required to put in place a legally binding process.
Every woman has a right to choose implantation, whether for cosmetic or reconstructive purposes. It is the government of Canada's unequivocal duty and responsibility to guarantee, to the best of its ability, that these women can fulfil that right safely. This bill takes a giant step in that direction and I can only hope that this government will have the common sense and the dignity to recognize these facts.
This is something I have been researching for two years. I do not take this issue lightly. I have spoken with experts in Canada. I have spoken with experts in the United States of America. The evidence is there. We have to make legislation or regulations. The Government of Canada has to protect these prostheses here in this country.
Private Members' Business
I urge this government to act upon this. This is not a votable bill, but I urge it to act upon this and to implement measures that will provide the safety for Canadian women.

Mr. Speaker, the Department of National Health and Welfare recognizes the importance of ensuring that dangerous or potentially dangerous breast prostheses are not sold in Canada. We also acknowledge that this is the intended purpose of Bill C-279 proposed by the hon. member.
However, Bill C-279 overlooks some important facts. The regulatory authority of the Food and Drugs Act and medical devices regulations is now comprehensive in ensuring that all medical devices meet the level of assurance that is being proposed.
But because many breast implants along with hundreds of other medical devices were on the market when the current regulations came into effect the manufacturers were not required to comply with some of the regulatory steps described below. But things have changed. The important elements of the hon. member's proposal are now already included in the current legislation.
Breast prostheses are regulated under the authority of the Food and Drugs Act. This legislation pertains to all medical devices including breast prostheses. To ensure that unsafe and ineffective medical devices are not sold in Canada the Food and Drugs Act prohibits any person from selling any medical device, including breast prostheses, that when used according to directions or under such conditions as are customary or usual, may cause injury to the health of the purchaser or user.
It prohibits any person from labelling, packaging, treating, processing, selling, or advertising any medical device in a manner that is false, misleading or deceptive, or is likely to create an erroneous impression regarding its design, construction, performance, intended use, quantity, character, value, composition, merit or safety.
The Food and Drugs Act provides authority for designated inspectors of health and welfare to enter at any reasonable time any place where medical devices are manufactured, prepared, preserved, packaged or stored.

Private Members' Business
Inspectors may examine anything used in conducting tests on a medical device. They also have the authority to sample, seize, detain or make copies of documents if they believe that the Food and Drugs Act or the regulations have been contravened.
The act also requires every medical device to be labelled and packaged in accordance with the medical devices regulations and to conform to prescribed standards. These broad provisions ensure that unsafe and ineffective medical devices are not sold in Canada.
Every medical device poses a degree of risk. However, those medical devices which pose an unacceptable health risk to Canadians are prohibited from being sold.
The definition of a medical device as stated in the Food and Drugs Act includes any article, instrument, apparatus, or contrivance, including any component, part, or accessory thereof manufactured, sold or represented for use in (a) the diagnosis, treatment, mitigation or prevention of a disease, disorder or abnormal physical state, or the symptoms thereof in man or animal, (b) restoring, correcting, or modifying a body function or the body structure of man or animal.
Breast prostheses are included in the definition of a device under the act. Therefore these products are subject to the many regulatory provisions of the act and the medical devices regulations.
The hon. member's bill proposes to include a new definition for breast prostheses which parallels, if not duplicates, the definition of a medical device already found in the act.
Both describe the product as an article, instrument, or apparatus or contrivance. Both include any component, part or accessory of a product. Both definitions relate to modifying, correcting, or restoring the body structure.
If breast prostheses are included in the definition of a medical device, then one must ask why it is necessary to have a separate definition for this specific device.
Obviously, the hon. member by introducing this bill wishes to introduce new legislative elements specific to breast prostheses. However, these important elements are already entrenched in the current legislation.
This proposal seeks to establish conditions which, if satisfied, would permit the sale of breast prostheses in Canada. The provisions require that tests must be conducted in respect of the device.
The medical devices regulations already require the testing of all medical devices before they are sold. Every manufacturer must conduct tests on the medical device and the test must indicate the benefit and the performance claimed for the device are justified.
Members will be aware that the products on the market were excluded from this requirement and that several breast prostheses were in effect grandfathered when the new legislation was passed. Any new breast implant being introduced would have to submit an indication that such tests had been done if they were currently being introduced.
This bill seeks to provide the Governor in Council with authority to make regulations respecting, among other things, the circumstances and conditions under which breast prostheses may be advertised.
I wish to point out once again that this authority is already provided for in the current legislation.
The Food and Drugs Act gives the Governor in Council the authority to make regulations respecting the offering, exposing and advertising for sale of any device to prevent the purchaser or the consumer of the device from being deceived or misled in respect of the design, construction, performance, intended use, quantity, character, value, composition, merit or safety of the device or prevent injury to the health of the purchaser or consumer. Over and above this, the Department of National Health and Welfare produced a handbook available to women considering breast implantation.
This bill makes further proposals which include first, requiring the department to issue the manufacturer of breast prostheses a notice of safety compliance which acknowledges that the prostheses is considered to be safe and effective for its intended use.
Second, the bill proposes banning the sale, manufacture or importation of breast prostheses which contain dangerous properties thereby ensuring that Canadians have access to safe breast implants.
March 16, 1992

These objectives are important to the government. The regulatory authority of the Food and Drugs Act and medical devices regulations is comprehensive in ensuring that these vital objectives are fulfilled.
Under the authority of the medical devices regulations a notice of compliance is required from the Department of National Health and Welfare prior to the sale of any new breast prostheses in Canada.
The issuance of a notice of compliance signifies that the department has received sufficient clinical and physical testing data to be satisfied that the medical device being reviewed does not pose an unacceptable risk to health.
The requirements contained in the regulations under the authority of the Food and Drugs Act ensure that the meaningful objectives of the hon. member's bill are achieved.
It is important to point out once again that no medical device is free of risk. The Department of National Health and Welfare reviews and assesses the data respecting the safety and effectiveness of implantable medical devices such as breast prostheses prior to their sale to ensure that unsafe and ineffective devices are not sold in Canada.
The second objective of the proposed bill concerns the banning of breast prostheses which contain dangerous properties including specified prohibited substances or are prescribed under regulations at a later date. This is not a new provision when considering the authority of the current Food and Drugs Act.
Section 19 of the Food and Drugs Act clearly prohibits the sale of any medical device that when used according to directions or under such conditions as are customary or usual may cause injury to the health of the purchaser or user.
The hon. member's proposal does not allow for risks and benefits to be considered and assessed. Instead the proposal requires that implants be banned entirely.
The Department of National Health and Welfare undertakes a scientific risk assessment approach when considering the safety and effectiveness of medical devices. This approach enables the department to assess fully the health risk by a substance present in a medical device. If a medical device poses an unacceptable health

risk which may cause injury to the health of the purchaser or user, it is prohibited.
In closing, I hope that I have illustrated that the regulatory provisions currently provided in the Food and Drugs Act and medical devices regulations are comprehensive in addressing the safety and effectiveness of all medical devices including breast prostheses.

Mr. Speaker, I was looking forward to rising and having a very factful and important debate on the subject of breast implants. I was looking forward to it a great deal. I expected that I could put forward some information that would be useful to the discussion and that would in fact help the government.
However, I have heard the hon. member for Winnipeg South, after two or three years of the opposition raising this question in the House of Commons, sanctimoniously say the legislation is adequate and sanctimoniously provide us with words like this is there to take care of any company that brings forward a product in a false, deceptive way, whose competition and merit and safety, et cetera are in question.
We have given two years of evidence in this House that this implant is not safe, that all implants are not safe. We have given indication after indication. We have met with the minister. We have provided him with documentation. We have had doctors in addition to Pierre Blais, who the government up and fired. We have provided documentation to the minister. In fact, what happens? Unsafe and ineffective medical devices, which this hon. member for Winnipeg South says will not be on the market and there are provisions to ensure they will not be on the market and are still on the market.
Do not be mistaken. We do not have a ban on implants in Canada. We have a voluntary moratorium on the use of implants. The day before the report was tabled with the food and drug administration calling for a ban on silicone implants except for reconstructive purposes, we had plastic surgeons in Quebec holding a press conference telling Canadian women breast implants were safe.

March 16, 1992
Private Members' Business
I have some real concerns about the effect of voluntary removal of breast implants from the marketplace when we have plastic surgeons insisting that they are safe. We know that the two companies, the company that produced the Meme implant, Surgitek, and the company that produced the majority of the silicone gel implants, Dow Coming, have withdrawn their products from the market. There are an awful lot of implants still lurking around in closets, in hospitals and doctors' offices that are available for use.
The sanctimonious, arrogant response from the member for Winnipeg South goes beyond the pale.
This piece of legislation proposed by the hon. member for Nepean is designed to clarify regulations to ensure that the problems experienced with this kind of implant do not happen again.
There is some speculation that some people from the company of Union Carbide for example were supplying silicone to Dow Coming in bulk. This is speculation. We do not have the entire proof, but we have some pretty exciting documentation. The company believes that the silicone gel used for the implants cannot be purified. Therefore, we have women with implants already in their bodies running the risk that they may fail and will have unpurified silicone gel running through their systems.
Strict labelling is useful but I have yet to talk to one woman who has had a breast implant who has been shown the label before she goes into surgery.
If I had any concerns about the legislation before us it is this. This legislation, according to the comments of the hon. member for Nepean in this morning's Ottawa Sun, calls for manufacturers to be the first to ensure that any breast implant is unequivocally safe. "This bill puts the onus on the manufacturer", it says.
It has been our experience in fact that manufacturers are the people who have been lying to us about the safety of these implants. They have not proven that they are safe. I would hope that this government would take its responsibility seriously and go beyond this bill. It should not rely on manufacturers but should listen to independent scientific study and studies in its departments to ensure that breast implants are safe.
Canada's slowness and Canada's ineptitude on this issue has created a situation where it is laughed at by the United States. The record of the United States is not much better.
We have been raising this issue in the House of Commons since before 1988 and we raised it regularly. I have asked to no avail in question after question in this House for the government to move on this matter.
Finally, after three attempts, our minister had a meeting last July with Marcella Tardif, Linda Wilson, and myself on the subject of breast implants. At that meeting, after he had told these women they were isolated cases, I know//e sais was formed.
In Quebec we had a meeting of 250 women. A couple of weeks ago and we had a meeting in Vancouver of 150 women. All those women were in pain, all were worried, and are desperate for sensitive medical help.
In addition we know that I know/Je sais has grown. In addition to Marcella Tardif in Quebec and Linda Wilson in B.C., Janet Fontaine in Ontario and Laurie Dobson in Alberta have formed an I know/Je sais.
We are facing a serious situation. The problem we are facing is that we are waiting for a report from Dr. Baines, the woman who said when watching the food and drug administration committee at work that the women who were complaining about this were the squeaky wheels trying to get the grease. She said that we were more concerned about lawsuits and winning lawsuits than we were about women's safety. This is the person we are relying on to come back to the House of Commons and to the minister to tell us whether or not breast implants should go on the Canadian market. I would say that Dr. Baines' position on this issue is somewhat suspect because she has made it very clear that she has no respect for us.
In fact those of us in this House from the opposition who raised this issue of great concern have been accused of being medical terrorists. I would say that those who are willing to continue to experiment on Canadian women should be considered medical fascists. We remember what happened to women in the 1940s used in testing and experimentation.
March 16, 1992

I know I have very little time and there is so much to say, but I just want to refer to a couple of concerns raised by women in their letters to me. One said: "I had a silicone breast implant inserted in 1974 in Vancouver. The plastic surgeon mentioned no risks and never did it occur to me that the implants would bleed silicone into my system. I have been sick chronically for the past 10 years at least, going from doctor to doctor, even a psychiatrist to no avail. Finally I have just been living in silent misery".
A woman, also from B.C., wrote: "I am writing concerning breast implants and their safety. I wish the Canadian government had responded earlier with legislation indicating that they really had the interests and safety of women in mind rather than waiting until pressure was applied by women who had seen what happened in the U.S. regarding this bill".
I do not want to take the time to read the other letters, but I have a thick file folder of letters from women regarding breast implants. I want to say that one of them told me she is contemplating suicide because she cannot get a disability pension. Nobody considers the condition a person ends up with from a failed implant or from side effects from the implant a disability or an illness. There are serious problems that have to be addressed by the government.
I have a chronology of events I would love to go through on this issue. I have it in both official languages, but I would hope, in concluding my remarks, that we could have all-party agreement for me to table the chronology of events on this issue.

Mr. Speaker, I appreciate your indulgence.
I guess there is not a woman in this country, that includes women on all sides of the House, who does not fear the threat of breast cancer. The statistics are there and my colleague, the member for Nepean, has raised them again, again and again as have other members of the House.
One million Canadian women can expect to contract breast cancer this year. The statistics on death are equally as staggering. I dare say there is not a woman in this House who does not have a relative or a close friend who has been the victim of this insidious disease.
One of the reasons we have to unanimously support this bill, notwithstanding the comments of the previous member, is that we have to send a message to the Minister of National Health and Welfare that women's bodies are not the subject of experimentation.
The onus and burden of proof should not be on the woman to show that she is being maimed and dying because of a breast implant. Rather, the onus and the burden of proof should be on the manufacturer.
My colleague, the member for Nepean, made a number of very telling points in her speech. The one point that she made in passing that bears repeating is that she and others have faced actual threat for raising this issue.
I would like to read a letter into the record that I think bears repeating. It is a letter written by-

-Real Laperriere Inc., already known for its public comments and I quote:

March 16, 1992
Private Members' Business
Madam:
It is with amazement that I read the stupid allegations you have made concerning breast implants.
I challenge you to repeat them outside the House of Commons, if you are brave enough to do so, which I doubt.
Before making such stupid statements, you should first check the Kerrigan Report, which was commissioned by Health and Welfare Canada.
It is a good thing -
and that is the most important part, Mr. Speaker.
-that ridicule has never killed anyone, you would be long gone.
This letter was sent to a member who is responsible in this House for women's health. And this letter refers to the report by the Minister of National Health and Welfare, this phoney report produced in spite of all the evidence heard even from within his own department.
I think it is obvious from this letter and from all the evidence heard and the proofs provided to this House that now is not the time to back down and shrink away from this problem. Now is the time to recognize that it is the Minister of National Health and Welfare's direct responsibility to protect women's health, especially considering that the manufacturers of this product are still distributing it on the market and that even a "voluntary recall" will not stop them.

These distributors, the people who are out making a buck on the bodies of women, are not going to be stopped by a voluntary recall. They need a very specific message. That message should come from the minister of health and should say to the likes of Real Laperriere, who frankly is a disgrace to the profession of medical distribution, that we do not take threats lightly in this House of Commons.

The person receiving those threats in Montreal does not take them lightly. It is a very serious matter. And it is incumbent upon the Minister of National Health and Welfare to make sure once and for all that he is going to put the health of women before the interest of manufacturers. What is more important, our health or a manufacturing process that results in such a disaster?
One million Canadian women will be faced with cancer this year. It could hit me or another female
member in this House, who knows? We at least want to be sure that our government is going to protect us. At present, the minister of health is not protecting us, quite the contrary. If it were testicular cancer or another form of cancer affecting the male members of this House that we were dealing with, I am convinced we would not have had to wait two or three years after Dr. Blais' resignation to at least do something about it.
Therefore, I urge all of you to support this bill as presented by my hon. colleague.

Mr. Speaker, I am very happy to stand in this House today and support the private member's bill of my colleague, the hon. member for Nepean, but I am very sad that it is necessary to do so.
Ever since I first became involved in this issue several years ago one sentence has been running through my head, and that sentence is: Show me the studies that show Canadian women that these implants are safe. It is a very simple phrase.
I have listened in committee. I have asked questions of experts on all sides of the issue, and the question I have posed over and over again is: Where are the studies that reassure Canadian women that these implants are safe? Is this a difficult concept? Is this something that is impossible to do?
Since this controversy arose we have discovered that Canadian women, and American women too, have been used in a political battle that is frightening in its ramifications. Last week some of us visited the United States and spoke with both legislators and staffers in Washington about this issue. We have heard that women who had breast implants, particularly those who had them in a post-mastectomy situation, have been particularly used by special interest groups, including their own doctors.
As my colleague from British Columbia said or my colleague from Nepean, or possibly both, "the silicone implant is particularly popular with doctors because it is easy to implant". Certainly we have no difficulty with that. But is "easy to implant" enough when we know that there are 6,000 women in this country alone who are having severe difficulties with this prosthesis? Is 6,000
March 16, 1992

women statistically insignificant to the members opposite?
I know that members opposite care what happens to the health of people in this country, but we have been subjected over the years with regard to breast implants to a question of smoke and mirrors. We have been told over and over again by people who have a vested interest in their success that they are successful and voices like the voices of I know//e sais are crying out in the wilderness and not being listened to. Again I ask: Where are the studies?
We supposedly have a department of health and welfare that is one of the finest in the world. It has protected Canadians on many occasions from drugs and other medical equipment that would be inappropriate. Where was it this time?
If there are studies, let the minister of health or let the parliamentary secretary to the minister of health, or let somebody on the government side come forward and table those studies so we can see them. The answer to the question is that there are no studies. There are no studies to prove that the implants are safe and there are no studies to prove that they are not harmful, and there is a dichotomy between those two.
We do not have studies. There were studies commissioned in the United States, of which we heard from various Congress people when we were in Washington last week, that fell apart within months of being commissioned, that lost half of their participants because of poor follow-up and because of no budget.
We have smoke and mirrors. We have people saying yes, they are safe and no empirical evidence to back this up.
There is not a great deal that we ask in this. We merely ask that the government show us that the Department of National Health and Welfare at the Health Protection Branch is indeed doing what it is supposed to do and that is protecting Canadian women. That is what the bill my colleague for Nepean is bringing forward and wants to do. It is a tragedy that it is not a votable bill.
What we want to know is where are the studies and show us now.

Mr. Speaker, I do want to emphasize that the health and safety of Canadian women are paramount and the subject of breast prostheses is a very important and a very current one.
The importance of ensuring that breast implants sold in Canada do not pose an unacceptable risk to health has been a concern of the Department of National Health and Welfare for many many years and it will continue to be. However, the legislative regime of ensuring that unsafe and ineffective medical devices are not sold in Canada should not be specifically tailored to one class of a medical device as is the case with this proposed bill, Bill C-279.
Let me make it very clear that every medical device does have some sort of degree of risk associated with it. Canadians choose to use medical devices including heart valves, pacemakers, X-ray machines, breast implants because the benefits associated with the device outweigh the risk to health. Canadians do benefit from medical devices in the form of increased mobility, longevity and the quality of life.
The health of women who have implants is the priority concern of the minister and of the department. The department has published a "Dear Doctor" letter advising all doctors across the country of the status of breast implants in Canada. Doctors have been kept informed and they have been kept up to date. A hotline was established to advise women. Last November, the department also identified specific labelling requirements for silicone gel-filled and saline-filled breast implants. Manufacturers of breast implants have been advised that specific cautions and warnings must be part of the labelling of all these products. This information assists women in consultation with their physicians to make informed decisions about the risks associated with breast implants.
There are a number of risks which are required and must be explained as part of labelling. This labelling information forms part of the type of information that is required to comply with the existing medical devices regulations. Manufacturers are advised that patients' considering silicone gel-filled and saline-filled breast implants should receive information pointing out the

speechtext:
There are 35 amendment motions for report stage of Bill C-13, an act to establish a federal environmental assessment process.

Motions Nos. 1, 3, 8, 9, 10, 12, 13, 14, 15, 17, 23, 24, 25, 27, 28 and 35, standing in the name of the Minister of the Environment, all propose technical corrections to one language only. They will be grouped for debate, with a vote on Motion No. 1 being applied to the other 15 motions.
Motions Nos. 2, 4, 5, 6, 7, 16, 20 and 26, standing in the name of the Minister of the Environment, propose technical changes, notably to bring the text of the bill into conformity with amendments made at the committee stage or to correct discrepancies within the bill. They will be grouped for debate, with a vote on Motion No. 2 being applied to the other seven motions.

Motions Nos. 11 and 18, standing in the name of the hon. member for Davenport, will be grouped for the purposes of debate but voted on separately.
Motions Nos. 19 and 29, also standing in the name of the hon. member for Davenport, will be grouped for debate. The vote on Motion No. 19 will apply to Motion No. 29.
Motions Nos. 21, 22 and 30, standing in the name of the Minister of the Environment, will be grouped for debate. The vote on Motion No. 30 will apply to Motions Nos. 21 and 22.

speakeroldname: Mr. Lee Clark (Parliamentary Secretary to Minister of the Environment):
speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of the Environment
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, first of all let me say to the House that it is a pleasure to be able to participate in our discussions today in my capacity as Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of the Environment and also to express to the House his regrets that he cannot be present during the course of today's discussions due to
commitments that take him to an important conference, the Globe 92 Conference, and to a meeting of the Canadian Council of Ministers of the Environment which is taking place during the course of the week.
The amendments which are grouped together before us at this stage are technical amendments. They are designed to correct some grammatical errors that were there in the latter stages of our process. In most cases they are designed to ensure that the French text is complete and accurate and so I do not think there are any areas of contention in respect to the amendments which are before us. I would like to take this opportunity, although perhaps I will do so again, to thank the members of the committee. As the committee knows we have been working on this legislation for many months.
Years.

speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of the Environment
speechtext:
My hon. friend says years. I say however with total conviction that the legislation which is before us is better legislation as a result of the extensive debate and study which took place. As we will see during the course of the day, a number of the amendments brought forward by the government are in fact an acceptance of amendments offered by various members of the committee. Indeed, although they are in the name of the Minister of the Environment in a very real sense members of the committee will recognize that they played a very significant role in that process.
I will come back to this at a later point, but I would like to thank those members for their very active work and for their co-operation. I think as a committee we set some sort of a model in terms of our ability to work together. We also called upon the assistance of two lawyers provided to us by the Canadian Environmental Network in the latter stages of our process which I think was a significant step and one which I suspect will be adopted by this committee and perhaps other committees in the future.

Mr. Speaker, having read both the English and the French versions of the bill I believe that these "technical amendments" raise very important points of principle and I would like to speak to those and I also would like to reply to the parliamentary secretary.
March 16, 1992



Bill C-13 will have a major impact on Canada's environmental future. Environmental assessment lies at the heart of a major effort at consciousness raising. The global ecosystem is not an inexhaustible resource.
That is why we unreservedly support the principle of an environmental assessment law for Canada. Furthermore, the Brundtland report considers impact studies to be a key to sustainable development.
If the experience of eastern Europe can teach us one thing, it is that blind development at the expense of environmental quality is not really development at all, since it is only short term and cannot last.
That is why the time has come to completely rethink our approach to development and the progress associated with it, because human progress depends on a healthy planet.

The bill we are examining today is the child of several years of court cases which have forced the government into action. It is also, as the parliamentary secretary said, the child of almost two years of intense work in legislative committee, work which transformed the bill before us from toothless legislation into something that at least has baby teeth.
The process of creating this bill was in itself unusual. We Liberals were strongly opposed to the original legislation. We heard from several dozen witnesses following second reading. These witnesses from industry and from environmental groups agreed with us. Tb its credit, I must say, and I would like to compliment the parliamentary secretary, to his credit, the government chose to heed many of the concerns that had been so strongly expressed and introduced substantial amendments.
In effect, as a result of our committee work, of which the parliamentary secretary was a vital cog, we were practically dealing with a whole new bill.
The committee then called a dozen witnesses to comment on the proposed amendments. Their interventions once again substantially influenced the bill. When
Government Orders
the final clause by clause review began, as was just said, we were again involved with two special witnesses who shared with us their significant expertise in environmental law. The result is this bill which is being reported on today.
We must remember the context within which this legislation has been developed. It comes after several years of intense controversy regarding the environmental assessment of major projects; Rafferty-Alameda, Oldman, ALPAC, Kemano, Point Anconi. The ongoing charade regarding these projects has resulted in deep public scepticism as to the integrity of the environmental assessment process. It has created widespread planning uncertainty in the public and the private sectors.
What we have virtually had in the last few years is environmental assessment through court order. In January of this year the Supreme Court of Canada delivered the final judgment on a string of court rulings on the application of the EARP guidelines. They affirm that the federal government has substantial constitutional powers to undertake environmental assessments.
We now have legislation before this House. This legislation will provide a predictable framework for project assessment. However, let me state that what is before us is far from the state of the art on environmental assessments. There are a number of fundamental conceptual flaws in the bill.
Let me enumerate a few. It does not apply to government programs and policies. It does not provide for compulsory intervening funding. It does not require the integration of environmental considerations such as the need for a project. It does not require alternative responses early enough in the planning process. It leaves the power to give the go ahead on a project to the minister with the most vested interest. It includes no direct mechanisms for the effective enforcement of the terms and conditions for product approval.
To begin with, we believe that the preamble of the bill should cite the peace, order and good government clause of the Constitution as a basis for proceeding. The Supreme Court ruling on the Oldman River dam determined that the earlier guidelines fell within the POGG power. This was a veiy significant interpretation and we believe it should be reflected in Bill C-13.

March 16, 1992
Government Orders
We also regret that the government has restricted application to the assessment process to physical works alone and did not include programs and policies. The past year has shown that a legislative basis is needed for environmental assessments of policies and programs. In June 1990, when this bill was first introduced by the then minister, the present Secretary of State, he promised that all proposals going before the federal cabinet would be subject to an internal environmental assessment. He promised that a statement on the environmental implications of new policies and programs would be made public at the time the cabinet initiative was announced.
Twenty-one months have passed and we have yet to see a single policy assessment announced. The current Minister of the Environment has stated again and again that these reviews have not been conducted because developing the methodology is very complicated.
It is not hard to interpret this as meaning that the government did not realize the implications of the statement of the now Secretary of State of Canada that it is delaying and stalling for time.
It is clear to us that just as this government had to be dragged kicking and screaming through the entire Canadian judicial system before it would implement project assessments, there needs to be a legally enforceable method for keeping its promise on policy assessments.
This act does not include the most basic principle of a truly participatory assessment system, a mandatory intervening funding program. While it gives the minister the power to establish such a program, it is purely discretionary.
Liberals view intervener funding as critical to the entire environmental assessment process. It vastly improves the decisions made and is one of the few avenues in society for public participation in the decisions regarding major project developments.
Individual Canadians are far ahead of their governments in their concern for environmental protection and in their desire for full and open government empowering people to protect the environment. To participate in environmental decision-making is key to moving toward a sustainable economy and building public understanding of the changes which need to be made.
Intervener funding is pivotal to this legislation. The examination to continue of the need of possible alternatives to a project is not applied at screening stage under this bill. Yet integration of environmental considerations and initial planning is essential to an effective assessment regime.
By limiting the consideration of need and alternative methods of meeting this need to the comprehensive study stage, environmental considerations are imposed retroactively after the project proposal has been developed. We also regret the responsible minister was given so much power to decide whether the project should go ahead.
Bill C-13 limits the environmental assessment panel to making only recommendations to the Minister of the Environment and the minister who is ultimately responsible. It leaves it entirely up to that minister, the latter, the responsible minister to determine what course of action should be taken following consideration of the review panel's report. This structure is open to inappropriate political considerations and political interference.
Liberals support a more independent structure. We support an independent agency which would administer and enforce the federal environment assessment process. It would report directly to cabinet. It would have the authority to improve an initiative, refer it to mediation or a panel for public hearings, or deny approval. Its decision in the end would then be subject to appeal to cabinet.
Finally, we are concerned that the bill includes no mechanism for effective enforcement of the terms and conditions of approval where a project has been approved.
In conclusion, I see this bill as a step forward, a step out of the quagmire of environmental assessment by court ruling. It will provide greater certainty for all players in Canada.
That being said, however, it is very clear that a future Liberal government will have to make many changes to this bill if it is to be truly of use as an instrument for promoting environmentally sustainable development.
Those are my comments on the technical aspects of the changes being made.
March 16, 1992

Government Orders

Mr. like to thank Beverley Hobby for the work she was able
Speaker, it has been some time in coming, getting Bill to provide to all of us at the committee stage to get us to C-13 on to the floor of the House of Commons. this point.
I for one have been with this process almost from the beginning including my appointment to the pre-study committee that considered Bill C-78, this bill's predecessor, so I am very happy to see it come to this stage.
I am also very happy to see the changes that have been added to this bill since the initial drafting occurred. I have a number of introductory remarks to make at this stage. Before I do that I just want to express one concern on the process that has occurred here in bringing the bill to the floor of the House today.
Of all the weeks in the year for the government to call this bill, it chose the one in which the Minister of the Environment has other commitments outside of Ottawa. He is attending Globe 92, a very important and interesting environment conference. The dates of the conference have been known for many, many months.
It just so happens that while this bill has been ready to be called to the House at report stage for some time now, this is the week that has been chosen.
I am most disappointed that despite all the work the Minister of the Environment has done to get us to this point that he is unable to be with us here today to see the conclusion of his and our efforts through the departmental and committee stages of this bill.
Before getting into the specifics of the amendments and later on the bill, I want to mention that I have a great deal of thanks for the Minister of the Environment for the direction he has allowed this bill to take.
He has been counselled very well by members of his staff, by departmental officials and in particular by members of FEARO and Department of Justice officials. The Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of the Environment has been most helpful during the committee stages.
I was most happy to work with the parliamentary secretary and officials from the Federal Environmental Assessment Review Office. The president, Michael Do-rais, and the vice-president, Karen Brown, have been most helpful throughout the whole developmental process. From the Department of Justice, I would very much
As my Liberal friend noted earlier the committee was aided in its work by two environmental lawyers. This is a first, I believe, for committee work in the House of Commons. The committee was very well served by Bill Andrews from the West Coast Environmental Law Association and Brian Pannell from McJannet, Rich in Winnipeg who provided their expert assistance during the amending process of the bill.
Obviously, any member of this House who has a chance to read Bill C-13 and compare it to former Bill C-78 would know of the vast differences between the two bills and the excellent contribution that both those individuals gave to us. It is a credit to the committee chair for allowing this process to fall into place and to be used.
I also want to have on record my particular and personal thanks to Louis-Philippe Cote from the Library of Parliament who was of great assistance in writing amendments for my side of the table and to my own staff and the research staff of my party, Bruce Thte and Sue Wilms, who have provided a tremendous amount of assistance in achieving the things that we have with this bill.
It will be seen as we go through the rest of these amendments today and at third reading later that the amending process and the amendments which were brought forward have vastly improved the bill.
I want to note one other thing at this point. I am hoping that the government takes note. This process began a little over two years ago. Actually, it probably began about four years ago when the need for environmental assessment legislation became known. But a little over two years ago the government recognized that specific legislation was going to require quite a bit of work.
The government began a process known as pre-study-ing the bill. In fact the committee was struck to pre-study former Bill C-78. I was appointed to that committee, and before the committee actually got to do most of its pre-study work the bill was introduced into the House and the committee got changed to a legislative committee looking at Bill C-78.

March 16, 1992
Government Orders
I want to stress very strongly that the government should be doing more pre-study work on bills of this nature, bills that are of great importance, bills that have a fairly technical nature to them.
It is obvious with the changes that this bill has undertaken that we could have saved a tremendous amount of time within the department and the ministry, and on all sides of the House, if in fact the pre-study stage had taken us almost to the point we are at today before the final bill was drafted and introduced for continuing debate in the House.
I was very supportive of the pre-study work. I was most disappointed when the pre-study ended and the bill was introduced as it was. As a result we have noted very clearly that the bill was drafted without all the benefit of the knowledge that was required to produce a specific and very important bill.
On that final point, I do want to note that we in the New Democratic Party who have worked on this bill and who have consulted on this bill recognize that Bill C-13 is perhaps the most important piece of environmental legislation that this government has had to deal with.
The Environmental Protection Act that passed in the Chamber a while ago was an important piece of legislation that took us forward in terms of environmental legislation. But with this bill on environmental assessment, if the people of Canada cannot participate in environment assessment, if the public is not involved in environmental assessment, and if the government is not serious about environmental assessment, the country and the world, the planet is doomed.
The people who are going to Brazil in June of this year recognize-and I know they already do because I have read the round-table reports and other reports that take us toward Brazil in June of 1992-that the importance of this legislation is one that we have to recognize right from the beginning of this debate.
The government has indicated through its acceptance of many of the amendments that have been put forward that it considers this bill to be important, and I am very pleased that we are going to take this in the next couple of days through to conclusion and put in place an environmental assessment bill that is going to serve the country well.
Like my colleague who spoke just moments ago, I want to stress in the beginning moments of this debate that in fact, if this bill were written by a New Democratic Party government it would have significant changes over and above those which we are taking here today.

Mr. Speaker, I am pleased to have an opportunity to speak on Bill C-13, particularly on this first grouping of amendments. They would certainly appear to be very technical in nature, as my friend the parliamentary secretary points out.
It is worth while to take a good look at these particular amendments. It is good to let the public know what these changes are about and what kinds of changes the government should also be including at this time and which it has neglected to do.
Most members in this House and many Canadians are aware that the environmental assessment process in this country really got going in 1974 with the rather loosely worded guideline to cabinet-that was during a minority government in 1972 to 1974. That was followed up by the EARP guidelines order that came in in 1984 which through a series of court decisions such as the Rafferty-Alameda decision and others has come to have the impact of administrative law.
I know the government has been concerned about the growth in the number of review panels that it has basically been forced by the courts to undertake. It has gone from about three panels a year four years ago to more than twenty per year now.
Moments ago I was looking at a ministerial document stamped secret, always handy to have during a debate. You can get a pretty good idea of what kinds of expenditures and PYs the government is planning in terms of this legislation and what kinds of loopholes it wants to build in and the ones it has left built in. One of the concerns that will be heard over and over during the debate this week is that the government tried, and successfully it seems, to court proof some sections of Bill C-13 to make it more difficult for the public interest to have certain kinds of projects properly assessed. There are also some Mack truck loopholes built in and we will certainly be dealing with those. Some of them are right within these motions and I will be dealing with them more specifically in a moment.
March 16, 1992

Of course there is the whole regulatory question. There are 15 sets of regulations, as my friend for The Battlefords-Meadow Lake reminded me this morning. He has done a terrific job in stick handling more than 100 amendments to try to clean up a very complex piece of legislation, perhaps too complex. When you think of 15 sets of regulations and pages and pages, there is an old adage that the longer the law, the more loopholes there are.
It is like income tax. The reason the government continues to produce huge amounts of tax laws is so that it can create loopholes for its friends.
Let us look at what the expected costs were when the Minister of Environment was having an assessment following the Speech from the Throne promise of what can be expected. In the 1989-90 fiscal year the A-base was expected to administer the 1984 cabinet guidelines order. This is immediately following the federal ruling on Rafferty-Alameda. It expected an A-base of $53 million. It only asked for a $500,000 increase and it wanted the person-year A-base to go up to 351 persons, an increase of 300 persons as a result of the court rulings. By 1993-94, it expected the A-base to increase to $118 million per year and person-years to go to 351. So the actual number of people it expected would be working would be 537 administering in relation to court rulings.
This is the process that got us where we are. The cabinet makes a loose ruling in 1974. In 1984 we get a natural cabinet order. In 1987 Our Common Future is published. More widely known as the Brundtland report, it recommends that all countries in the world have a mandatory, legislatively based environment assessment process. By 1987 it came to be recognized that it is not only cost effective and cost efficient, it is the only way we can actually have sustainable development. We must start right at the initial screening process and look at the alternatives to projects which regrettably, as my colleague for The Battlefords-Meadow Lake has pointed out, were dispensed with by the government. It refuses to accept looking at alternatives at the most important stage, right when a project is being conceptualized. The importance of having these kinds of assessments is now globally recognized because the environment in many, if not most areas of the world, is continuing to decline and
Government Orders
be degraded because of inappropriate construction, development, dumping practices and so on.
The government made a commitment. Our own Prime Minister in the fall of 1987 endorsed, as did the premiers, the Brundtland commission report and for the past four years, first Bill C-78 and now subsequently Bill C-13, which has risen from the ashes of Bill C-78, has finally made its way to the floor of the House. Today we are looking at the amendments which are proposed by the government, by my friend for The Battlefords-Meadow Lake and my friend in the Liberal Party who described this bill as having baby teeth. I am not sure the baby teeth have even grown in yet. I would say it is a bit gummy yet. We are going to have to see how the government goes about gumming some of the big projects that are out there like James Bay, Rafferty-Alameda, Oldman dam, Kemano II, and Point Aconi because there is somewhere between $20 billion and $60 billion worth of projects that have been conceptualized and are coming off the drawing boards or, like Oldman, are in fact there.
Legislation can often be judged by how a government has been acting in the period leading up to that legislation. If one looks, for example, at Oldman one has to ask why the Minister of Transport has not even put in place an order for which he has power, authority and control under the Navigable Waters Act to require that the impoundment not be filled any further. TTie studies are still being done. The panel is still there. The Supreme Court of Canada has ruled on it and this government will not even live up to a Supreme Court of Canada ruling.
When I say that this is gummy legislation, it is administered by the Gummy Bears. We have the Minister of the Environment, the Minister of Transport and all of these other ministers. They have a piece of legislation full of loopholes, full of discretionary authorities and powers, 15 sets of regulatory authority, bureaucrats all over the place and you have to look for will.
Mr. Speaker, I know you, having played centre in football, understand the need for will. You have always exercised your will well here, but I am just not quite so confident about some of your colleagues when I look at some of the major projects that are out there that they have exercised their will and their discretion in the best interest of the environment.

Government Orders
We look at the major projects out there and how they have fumbled the ball time after time. You never missed a snap. I have looked at the old footage. But these ministers have played a lot of ball without a helmet and it worries the public out there that this government has not really shown the kind of really serious interest in protecting the water quality, the forests, the wildlife, air quality and even our international commitments on global warming, the ozone and so on.
I would describe this as pretty gummy legislation. The Liberals say there are still baby teeth. We may hear from the minister later in the week that this is dentured legislation.
Let me look, in somewhat more depth, at some of the particular projects in relation to this legislation and see where it would lead us. There is the discretionary power and the ability of the government to move to mediation rather than to public review panels and to not have included legislatively, as it should be, intervener funding which should be in there with a trigger that the public can access so that they know if there is an initial screening being done, they can trigger certain kinds of funding. If it is a review panel or mediation it is there and it can be triggered if necessary through the courts.
The government is sending out a mixed message. It is giving the hubbub, you do not need to worry message to the provinces and the territories and it is giving: "Don't worry, be happy"-you know the little whistling song, Mr. Speaker-to the private sector: "Don't worry, be happy. As soon as this is in place, you will be able to go on with your major projects because we have got all these discretionary opportunities with this legislation".
As my friend, the hon. member for LaSalle-Emard pointed out, there is going to be an election fairly soon and the New Democrat government is very likely going to have to redraft some major parts of this legislation because it is pretty loosey-goosey. I know, Mr. Speaker, that you do not like loosey-goosey legislation and neither do I. We should have got nose to nose and shoulder to shoulder a little earlier on all sides of the House and moved forward a better quality of legislation, but I guess the government had more members and it decided that was not the way to go.
My friend from The Battlefords-Meadow Lake did do an excellent job in getting it patched up a bit. The Liberals swung in there from time to time and got a few Johnson & Johnson bandages on to the legislation, but there is work to be done in the next few days. I hope the government is going to co-operate in putting some serious thought to accepting some of the major amendments that we have proposed. I know it has accepted many, but there are some more to be accepted. I think the public wants to know that this is going to be truly workable and useful legislation.
I was looking, just for a moment, at what is called the "Communications Synopsis". It is stamped "secret, for the ministers' eyes only" but it is always worth having a look at. It is called "anticipated impact of having this legislation passed". It is anticipated that 90 per cent of Canadians are going to think very highly of it.
It is expected that media attention could be a four on a scale of five. The media are going to give this a four, and possible headlines. These are the headlines expected. I will just give you two headlines. The positive one that the minister expects is "Government Reform to Aid Sustainable Development", the negative one could be if things did not go well with the media this week: "Feds Back Off Environmental Promises".
I look forward, over the next few days, to participating in the various motions as they come up. I regret that there are only 10 minutes with each opportunity, but I suppose there will be a number of opportunities for me to carry on in dissecting this legislation so that the public knows exactly what there could and should be in it and what is not there.

Mr. Speaker, I am pleased to be able to add my voice to the debate on this very important legislation and on the so-called technical amendments that the parliamentary secretary has put forward this morning.
I wonder about the timing of the introduction of this legislation. One wonders if the legislative agenda of this government is really as out of control as it appears when the Minister of the Environment has to attend, as the parliamentary secretary has indicated, a very important
March 16, 1992

conference in Vancouver and yet the government chooses this week to introduce this legislation, Bill C-13.
The Minister of the Environment has acknowledged in committee that it is: "One of the most important projects to be introduced in this Parliament". I agree with that. Bill C-13 attempts to go on from the 1984 cabinet guidelines order, which was never intended as an environmental assessment review process.
It was a stop gap measure because of the vacuum in legislation. What has flowed from that 1984 cabinet guidelines order is a large number of court cases because of the vacuum in legislation.
The committee studying Bill C-13 has worked very long and hard on making the necessary amendments. I want to give a lot of credit to my colleague from the Battlefords-Meadow Lake because I know the introduction of 111 amendments takes an awful lot of energy and I would also like to give some credit to, and unsolicited of course, my colleague from the Liberal Party because of all the work that has been done.
There has been a lot of co-operation in committee to try to make this environmental assessment process more clear and to give more certainty. We have seen the sector of court cases, the Rafferty-Alameda process, the Point Aconi process, the Oldman River process, the Kemano project in British Columbia, in my province.
This legislation is trying to stop the use of the courts as a means of determining legislation and to take it back to the House of Commons. It is our responsibility as legislators to do this. It should not be left up to the courts. It is a quest for clarity and for certainty, but it is not quite there yet.
There are other major gaps in this legislation that we will be highlighting in the coming days because it is not quite good enough for us to support yet. This is the most important environmental legislation to come before this House in many years. We are not prepared to give a rubber stamp of approval until we are certain that it has proceeded far enough so that those court cases will no longer have to be the mechanism where people can get involved in environmental assessment. We want a transparent process so that the public can be involved in assessing the environmental projects or any projects
Government Orders
brought forth with federal funding. We also want it seen to be a transparent process so that the public is involved.
Many amendments have yet to be debated. The regulations, as has been pointed out, are crucial to the enforcement of this legislation. They are the teeth, the baby teeth, the dentures, whatever. The regulations are the real teeth.
We need some reassurance that we will be able to look at them. As legislators we are here to fulfil our responsibility to the people of Canada in a serious way to make sure that environmental review is done properly and done responsibly. That is what we are elected to do. It is not what the judges are appointed to do.
I also want to point out that we found how far we have come since 1984 with the cabinet guidelines order, how much has happened. We need to have some sort of time line that this bill, even if it is passed, gets reviewed. That is another amendment that has been put forward by my colleague, the hon. member for The Battlefords-Meadow Lake.
In conclusion, this is going to be a very interesting couple of days. I hope that the Minister of the Environment and his cabinet colleagues will see fit to be participants in this debate. It is, as the minister himself said, the most important environmental legislation to be put forth in this Parliament.
