speakeroldname: Mr. Lee Clark (Parliamentary Secretary to Minister of the Environment):
speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of the Environment
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I would like to begin by noting again that a series of motions is before us which indeed are technical. Having said that, I must congratulate hon. members on their ability to turn debate on such technical amendments into such far-ranging and interesting topics.
We have before us a series of motions designed in some cases to remove redundant or unnecessary words, because we are anxious to have the legislation as tightly drafted as can be; in some cases to add additional words by way of explanation; and to ensure the words are used in a consistent fashion throughout the bill.
I would also note that during clause-by-clause consideration the committee amended subclause 5(1) to clarify that an environmental assessment must be carried out before a responsible authority can take any action. This required changes as well to subclauses 5(2), 5(l)(c) and 5(2)(b) in order to ensure consistency throughout.
I would hope, therefore, that we could give careful but speedy consideration to the specific motions before us.

Mr. Speaker, in addressing only Motion No. 261 would like to say that we are very pleased to see the government agreeing with the principle that it is important to ensure that irrevocable decisions are dealt with before they become irrevocable and in harmony with the purposes of the bill as set out in clause 4. Particularly I would refer to purpose (a), which is to ensure that the environmental effects of projects receive careful consideration before responsible authorities take actions in connection with them. It seems to me that Motion No. 26 falls within the spirit of this purpose.
Government Orders
I would like to conclude by putting on record the fact that under the Liberal government in 1984 an assessment process was outlined in the Order in Council guidelines on environmental assessment matters which ensured, and I quote from the text, that "environmental matters are to be taken into account throughout the planning and implementation of all proposals falling under federal jurisdiction. This is to be done before commitments or irrevocable decisions are made".
The government has done well with Motion No. 26.1 congratulate the parliamentary secretary for having taken this action.

Mr. Speaker, I rise to speak in the House on this environmental bill.
It is true this set of amendments deals with technical amendments, but these technical changes are very important. For example, the set of amendments deals with projects to be assessed, excluded projects, Crown corporations, Indian bands, appointment of mediators, joint review panels, and provincial agencies.
I want to deal with these in a somewhat broader context. Let me say right away that there is no more important an issue in Canada and in the world than the environment. When the Minister of the Environment allegedly said that our kids should not go out in the sun, or parents should be very careful about letting their kids going out in the sun, people were shocked. I think people are still reacting to that.
I had a chance to speak to some of my colleagues and friends on the west coast who are particularly interested in the environment. Indeed some of them founded a group called Greenpeace in one of my friend's basements a number of years ago in Kitsilano, in Vancouver. Of course Greenpeace now is a world environmental agency, but it started right here in Canada, right in my own backyard in the Vancouver area.
My friends who were involved in the founding of Greenpeace tell me that the minister's warning about the sun and about the kids going out in the sun is only the beginning. As a matter of fact it is chilling, what they tell us.

The warming is chilling.

March 16, 1992
Government Orders

The warming is chilling. I do not intend to make a pun or make fun of that. This is a deadly serious mattef.
What may lie ahead for us is a very different world than what we were used to. That is why I say the environment is the most important issue.
I look, as do all of us, at the letters I get from my riding. We now get faxes and telephone calls. They are very interesting, at least in my case. I note when environmental matters come up that they are inevitably from young people. When we talk to young people in they schools they ask us about the environment. I remember talking to students in the Coquitlam and Port Moody schools in my riding, a suburb of Vancouver with excellent schools and students who are very motivated in environmental concerns. Inevitably the question is the environment.
I was thinking today about the upcoming election. Someone mentioned that it may be within a year. I remember an all-party debate at Centennial High School in Coquitlam, British Columbia, during the last election. The teachers did a bit of a poll as to which party's candidate was winning. I must say that I was somewhat shocked because I was in third place in that poll as we went in.
I remember we only had a short period of time, a few minutes, and I chose to comment on the environment. When I came out of the debate I was quite far ahead in the poll because clearly I had chosen an issue the students were really interested in. They wanted to vote for someone who would champion such issues.
I took part in the study of the previous bill on the environment in the last Parliament. I was on the legislative committee. Having had that experience, I want to congratulate the members who took part in this legislative committee, especially the member for The Battle-fords-Meadowlake. When he goes back to speak to the high school students in his riding in Saskatchewan I hope he will say: "I took part in the process that led to Bill C-13" because it is really important.
I say to the hon. member who is behind me in the House that I took part earlier this year in a bill on gun control. It took a long time and a lot of effort. I remember thinking at the time: You do not get a lot of credit for this; you do not get your name in the headlines on this. There is a lot of work behind the scenes. It is a heck of a lot of work and I want to congratulate him.
The world may not know what he is doing, but young people will know and are concerned about what he is doing. As a matter of fact, I noticed that the hon. member for The Battlefords-Meadow Lake has spoken on this issue a number of times. I was just trying to find copies of his speech. I just want to quote the hon. member when he said: "Our children are inheriting a country which is sick and diseased compared to the state of our country a generation ago. Our ozone layer has been destroyed to the extent where the federal Minister of the Environment has warned that our children should not expose themselves to the sun. Many of our lakes and rivers are dead and dying. Our forests are sold off in unimaginably large tracts to pulp and paper companies. We continue to encourage global warming and our children have been robbed of the opportunity to share our environment with many species of animals, plants, fish and birds now extinct through bad choices we have made as individuals and through our government. We can change the future".
I hope this bill will go some way to changing that future because the environment is our future. Canada must have the best environment in the world, and that is what we should be committed to as politicians. I hope this bill will go some way to doing that.
I just want to go over a couple of parts in the bill and make some comments on them. The bill, as I understand it, sets out to trigger the set-off of environmental assessment. We have seen a number of projects such as the Rafferty-Alameda project in Saskatchewan, the James Bay project in Quebec, the Oldman Dam project in Alberta and the Kemano project in British Columbia. The bill triggers these environment assessments. The intensity of the assessment from a simple screening to a full panel or mediation is dealt with; what sort of projects, activities or undertakings are to be assessed; the factors to be assessed are taken into account; who is to do the assessing; the role of the public; and the responsibility and authority of the minister.
Now it is very important that these assessments be clear and we set out a procedure. We in the New Democratic Party would like to see a better environmental assessment procedure. We believe the assessment should be done by an independent agency free from political pressure or influence peddling and the decision should be final and binding.
March 16, 1992

I am going to conclude there and come back later in the debate to speak about the role of the environmental community which was involved in this bill, and I applaud that, and some of the shortcomings of the bill which still treats environment and economic development as tradeoffs. I want to talk about where I think we can strengthen the bill by making a much clearer process, a stronger process and better public input.
Let me conclude where I began. As the hon. member from The Battlefords-Meadow Lake has said, I have visited his riding and it is a beautiful environment.
I want to conclude by saying that the environment is the major issue for the future. The young people of Canada understand that. They demand that their members of Parliament, as far as possible, put partisanship aside, as has been done a lot in this committee, to strengthen this bill, to make a strong environmental bill with clear protections and a clear process when we are to begin big projects in this country which could damage our environment. We have just begun the fight.

Mr. Speaker, I wanted to add a few words here. I am prompted by my friend from British Columbia who has visited my constituency and travelled in particular to Meeting Lake Regional Park at one point. He rode in an antique vehicle that had been provided to us for the afternoon on a beautiful summer day on the banks of the beautiful lake at Meeting Lake Regional Park in northwest Saskatchewan.
The hon. member speaks volumes when he talks about the importance of the environment to us as human beings. We all would be much poorer without the ability to have those clean lakes and the clean air around us.
I visited India last year for the world conference with the Commonwealth Parliamentary Association. I must say touring a country with a population of 850 million people and trying to find a clean lake like we have in northern Saskatchewan is a task that I do not think anyone could perform.
We have a lot of work to do in this world and starting here at home is a must.
Government Orders
The hon. member talked about regulations and he talked about working on Bill C-17, the gun control legislation. I had to tell him, as we had discussed privately during that bill, my major concern with the gun control legislation was the lack of the ability of members of Parliament and others to have access to and discuss the regulatory process.
On the member's work on that committee, it defined a regulation-making process that gave members of Parliament and members of the other place an opportunity to have a look at the regulations prior to their coming into force and being a part of the process that flows out of that legislation.
The member from British Columbia will note that one of the amendments that will come up later today is virtually word for word from Bill C-17.
I put on the table for this environmental legislation an amendment which would provide members of this House and members of the other place an opportunity to review the stacks of regulations that are going to come down in relation to this particular piece of legislation.
I am most concerned that in fact the regulation-making process is going to be the one that is going to have the most follow-up when Bill C-13 is finally law and we are operating with it in developing the environmental assessment process in Canada.
I would like to see, and I will be urging later in the day that my amendment, which was modelled on the one put forward by the hon. member in Bill C-17, regarding the regulatory process will be accepted by the members on the other side and the members to my right in the Liberal Party.
I do not have enough time to speak about this section, Mr. Speaker, and I regret that but I understand the rules and will be happy to follow the rules. This set of amendments, while it deals with a broad range of subjects, inserts a few technical matters into those sections, but in particular, Motion No. 20 dealing with the joint review panel is one that I would like to say a few words about.

Government Orders
The process of the review panel matters is most important to us. When we heard from one provincial minister speaking on behalf of the Canadian Council of Ministers of the Environment, he put up quite an argument that in fact the provincial process is one that has to be the governing process.
I feel very strongly that environmental assessment legislation has to be federal in nature with its strengths resting with the federal government. As we know from the environment committee's report tabled earlier this year, the environment knows no boundaries.
The environment does not recognize these historical and political boundaries that we as humans have drawn on the maps. When toxic materials go into the air and when toxic materials flow into rivers they do not stop when they come to a provincial border. They flow on and they flow on and the damage that can result is most intense.
We heard from the people in the Northwest Territories who argued very strongly that actions that take place in northern Alberta for example will have devastating effects in the Northwest Territories because of the way in which the rivers flow.
We have to be most informed, knowledgeable and sensitive to those facts.
I must say there has been a significant strengthening of the environmental and administrative credibility of the federal environmental assessment process within this bill.
The government has made it clear in the bill that joint panels must adhere to specific standards. These joint panels are an essential part of the process and a major part of this piece of legislation.
Those specific standards which the joint panels must adhere to include factors to be considered, participation in subsequent reports. The government has also through this legislation ensured a clear federal presence on the joint panels which will be put in place.
I believe that in this case the legislation is quite clear and joint panel reviews must meet the same requirements as federal panel reviews. This means that it is the standards that are set by the federal process that in fact run supreme in terms of the over-all assessment process and we will all benefit as a result of that.
In conclusion, I just want to point out to those who are watching part of the conditions under which a joint panel operates. As you know, Mr. Speaker, because I know you have read this legislation very closely as you do all legislation that in this case the minister appoints or approves the appointment of a chairperson for the joint panels and appoints at least one other member of that panel. That ensures that the federal presence is very secure.
The legislation, thanks to amendments which were brought forward, ensures that the members of the panel are to be unbiased and free from any conflict of interest relative to the project. That is not always easy to do, but it is guaranteed here in the legislation that the panel members must not have a bias or a conflict when it comes to reviewing the project on the panel.
Of course the Minister of the Environment fixes or approves the terms of reference for that joint panel. That is a very positive step.
There are hours worth of matters to be discussed here. Mr. Speaker, I see you signalling that my time is up. I recognize and understand that and will continue the debate as we go through the day.

Mr. Speaker, this is an interesting series of amendments that we are dealing with now.
Some of them touch on the regulatory provisions of Bill C-13. Many people would think that those are something that would only be of interest to lawyers or specialists or certain people in corporations who are proposing projects and might be particularly interested in some of those regulatory provisions.
As I have had an opportunity to discern, these 15 sets of regulations look a bit like a gigantic box of Cheerios. There are all kinds of loopholes being built into these regulations that neither the members of the legislative committee, who were scrutinizing the legislation, nor in fact the parliamentary secretary had a chance to go through. I am certain the minister has not even had a chance to go through all of the regulations.
It is important to put on the record some of the concerns that we have even in terms of this part of the process. There has been a growing and good habit on the government side of including more and more of the
March 16, 1992

regulatory provisions of legislation with the legislation at the time of its passage.
If the government does not include the regulations, then such as we found with the recent farms legislation, an opportunity is placed right within the legislation for regulatory scrutiny. Regrettably, the government has prohibited that opportunity so far. It still has an opportunity at this time to introduce such an opportunity.
It is very important where the regulatory spread is so wide and where so many people of good interest have urged the government to include the opportunity for policies to be evaluated through environmental assessment right at its initial promulgation. Just as with a project as policies are being developed they should be scrutinized, just as should be the budget and development projects outside of Canada that either make use of Canadian capital or resources, be it intellectual or direct development resources.
I would like to bring to the attention of the House some of the concerns that have been raised by the national environmental law section of the Canadian Bar Association in terms of some of the regulatory sections that are now being worked. There is out there for some consultative purposes a work book on regulations.
In what would appear to the public to be a good piece of legislation, one would assume in its mandatory study list to include things such as new nuclear reactor sites, new major hydroelectric dams, new major forestry proposals that would impact on an entire watershed. One would think that those sorts of things would be there.
I noticed under the nuclear and related facilities assessment section by the legal community the following was found. I will try to simplify it and just get to the nub of it. It is the kind of regulatory exclusion that the public would have some difficulty digesting.
It says that the limit for items (a) through (g) in the new section on regulations related to new nuclear facilities is not justified in the view of the definitions of projects under subsection (2)(1) of bill C-13.
In addition, NELS apprehends that almost all of the limits on inclusion of projects in the comprehensive study list under this heading have been imposed not on the basis of any environmental criteria but rather to ensure minimal interference of the environmental asses-
Govemment Orders
sment process with the ordinary course of business of the Canadian nuclear industry.
For example, the limit under (c) to nuclear reactors with a power capacity greater than 30 thermal megawatts would effectively remove from the comprehensive study the slowpoke reactors which Atomic Energy of Canada Limited has proposed for such densely populated and sensitive locations as hospitals and university campuses.
This is what we have. As I said earlier, the process began in 1974. We got our first cabinet directive for Canada in 1984 that was consolidated into the 1984 cabinet guidelines order.
In 1987 the Brundtland report Our Common Future recommended to all countries in the world that there be mandatory legislated environmental assessment processes that would include the public. By 1988 the gears had been put into forward motion here in Ottawa.
The bureaucracy was drafting, in justice and in other departments, legislation to come before the House. During that period 80 government departments and agencies were consulted. I have gone through one of these "for minister's eyes only" stamped "secret" documents for what was going on in there.
It is kind of alarming because we can go back three years and find on page 4 regarding departmental positions: "Energy, Mines and Resources supports the legislation", that is referring to the legislation before us today, "but opposes applying it to Petro-Canada and Atomic Energy of Canada Limited. Finances concerned about intervener funding, the inclusion of Crown corporations and the magnitude of uncertainty of the costs of the proposal". On it goes.
As the consultative process was going on, we find different ministers and different agencies trying to pave ways within the legislative process where they can find ways to slip out of, slide out of, avoid having to undergo even an initial screening.
As many people have come to realize, the court judgments that were coming down on the 1984 cabinet guidelines order, whether it was on Rafferty-Alameda, the Oldman through the Supreme Court of Canada decision earlier this year, the court rulings in relation to the Great Whale or the court process involving Kemano II or the Kemano completion process in British Colum-

March 16, 1992
Government Orders
bia, there was starting to be a growing body of administrative law.
Two other processes were going on. Ministers and agencies were trying to find permanent loopholes. At the political level, government ministers were trying to convince the private sector, the provinces and the territories not to woriy about this new legislation because the loopholes for them would not be seen immediately within Bill C-13, but they would come in all of these regulatory mechanisms.
Take the one example I raised. Why should Candu's new phase of nuclear reactors, the slowpokes, because they are less than 30 thermal watts, be excluded? Why should existing sites which may be more dangerous than proposed new sites be excluded?
If we are going to have environmental assessment legislation that is worth anything, it means we get out there and identify from a-I do not want to use overly complex language here-truly ecologically sustainable development perspective what are the best ways of maintaining the Brundtland definition of "sustainable development", which is that we pass on to future generations, a habitable, liveable, sustainable ecology.
That does not seem to be the case. I do not point my finger at anyone, but it does not seem to be what we are doing in the country. As I said earlier, I see the chair of the Rivers Defence Coalition here in the House today, Pat Moss, who has worked long and hard to get sensible policies applied to a major project in British Columbia, Alcan's second phase of the Kemano project.
People like Miss Moss look at Bill C-13 and say: "How would this apply to a project that already has $.5 billion spend on it in the area that I live. Would I be better with the 1984 guidelines order, or would I be better with Bill C-13?" What we do know in terms of the guidelines order is that the government, rather than even having the assessment procedures apply, used what is now recognized as an unconstitutional approach, the same Order in Council powers to exempt the project from an environmental assessment.
That demonstrates to the informed environmental community in Canada the will of the government. If the will of the government on a project that is here now in 1992 and is before us is to sneak around having an assessment, what kind of credibility should members of this House or the public put in a hidden regulatory process?
That is why it is very important to examine this series of motions. We certainly look forward to hearing from members on the government side as to exactly what
kinds of assurances we can have that there is not going to be an undoing, through the regulatory Governor in Council processes of this legislation what members such as the for The Battlefords-Meadow Lake and others have fought so hard to have placed within the legislation in a clear and understandable way, through a process with Bill Andrews and Mr. Pannell, that was unique and informative and had great potential.
I look forward to pursuing both the regulatory and the policy matters in the next section of amendments.

Mr. Speaker, as we have heard in the speeches today in this House, the complexity of this bill is becoming clear. There are major motions still being put forward at the report stage of this bill.
I would like to focus on Motion No. 26 in particular. The language in it is: "before irrevocable decisions are made". It is very clear from our most recent history on environmental concerns that we have the language in this legislation to ensure that environmental assessment carries through before irrevocable decisions are made. That means that, yes, things will have to slow down, that maybe development is not going to go at the pace the major corporations would want it to.
Canadians have told members of this House that there cannot be development without some consideration for the environment. We now know that the Supreme Court decision on the Oldman River has come down. This is not just a victory for the environmental movements, it is also a victory for the people who made it clear in the language of this motion that irrevocable decisions have been made. The Oldman River dam is now reportedly 25 storeys tall. The taxpayers of Alberta and the taxpayers of Canada will be the ones who are paying the bill on that. This is not responsible behaviour. It was pushed through with the assumption that all was going to be well and that provincial jurisdiction was going to be paramount.
The Supreme Court has decided: "No, wait a minute. There is federal paramountcy on environmental concerns". The Oldman River decision is crucial to the way we jig the kind of jurisdictional squabbles between the levels of government.
The federal government has to have supreme authority on environmental issues. It just makes good sense. Often in this House good sense does not prevail. Rivers do flow across provincial boundaries, air flows across not just provincial boundaries but international boundaries. My colleague from The Battlefords-Meadow Lake has pointed out that the environment does not respect the
March 16, 1992

nice little maps we have drawn on the globe. Therefore, we have to find the best way of determining how to care for the environment. Canada, that is the federal government, has to have the supreme authority on those decisions. Canada is the one that is speaking, not just for the country but for all the people in each of the territories and the provinces.
Motion No. 26 makes certain that the environment has to be considered before irrevocable decisions are made, so that the tax dollars that went into that 25 storey structure on the Oldman River will not be wasted in the future. It is not irresponsible environmentalists that are trying to block progress, it is very responsible environmentalists wanting to ensure that the project will only proceed when all things have been considered. That is the complexity of this bill and we will be talking about it over the next few days. For those people who are watching, please bear with us. It is complex and we want to do the best we can for environmental assessment in Canada because it is so important.

He said: Mr. Speaker, briefly the explanation of this motion is that there is a provision in the proposed bill on environmental assessment whereby the minister can delegate to any person, body or jurisdiction the authority to conduct any part of this screening of a comprehensive study of a project or the preparation of a screening report.
Having done so and having delegated that authority, the proposed legislation is silent on whether or not the minister can revoke this authority, if he or she deems fit to do so.
With this amendment, we are proposing to the government that it be made quite clear and specific that if for any reason the minister deems that the process is not being conducted satisfactorily, then the delegation of authority can be revoked by the same minister in charge of that process.
Mr. Speaker, with your permission, I will also deal with motion 18 since you have already called it. What we are proposing on the Liberal side is an amendment to shift the decision-making responsibility from the minister who proposes that particular project to the entire cabinet. This may sound a bit dramatic and sweeping but nevertheless decisions are made in cabinet which are far reaching, national and of a scope that sometimes reaches

Government Orders
well beyond the boundaries of one district or one province.
In clause 4 of the bill, the purpose of the bill is expressed in the manner that it justifies the kind of amendment I submit. There is a collective responsibility that ought to be discharged by the entire cabinet and not only by the proposing minister, including the Prime Minister. In doing so, I submit that actually the four purposes outlined in the early part of the bill, which sets out what this bill intends to achieve, would not be compromised. It would be accomplished and accomplished better.
In this amendment there is also a provision for proceeding by way of Order in Council, rather than by way of a decision that is not made public. As you know, an Order in Council has to be made known to the public by way of The Canada Gazette.
This is a very important step because it gives a clear and public record of the decision made by the government, by cabinet. It spells out the conditions of the approval including the mitigation measures in the approval, and it does empower the responsible authority to enforce the conditions of the order.
So there are several goals that are achieved by way of this amendment. They are: enforce the bill, make the public information process valid and real, and also give the enforcing authority the validity and the power and the weight of public opinion in the process of enforcing the measure itself.
So for these reasons which flow from clause 4 of the bill in which the purposes are outlined, as I already indicated a few times, the amendments are submitted to this House in the hope that they will be received favourably.
If Motion No. 18 were to be accepted, it would go a long way in defusing some of the criticism that is being addressed to this bill.

Mr. Speaker, I want to commend the member for Davenport for bringing this matter to our attention today.
It is obvious that there is a bit of a failing in that part of the bill as to the time when the ministers can delegate authority for various matters and not have a termination clause present.
I want to commend the member for bringing this to our attention today. I want to urge the government and other members to support this amendment because of its necessity.
Just to follow on the argument in support of the member's amendment, I want to quote a brief statement from the Minister of the Environment when he appeared before the legislative committee studying Bill C-13 on October 10, 1991.
The Minister of the Environment said that "while the amendments and proposed regulatory process are the product of more than four years of work, the bill before us will affect all parts of our society and it will create a new dynamic in environmental assessment. More than 80 departments and agencies have been involved, as well as the provinces, the territories, environmental and industry groups, and many others. Let us keep in mind that this act reflects a consensus which, in turn, reflects the growing understanding and concern Canadians share about the relationship between our economic activities and our natural environment".
I will just continue the quote for another brief second. The Minister of the Environment said: "I believe that the Canadian Environmental Assessment Act provides us with a flexible instrument with which we can meet the environmental challenges of the future. This bill constitutes a major advance in the field of environmental assessment. It encourages projects and practices that respect the environment, and it increases the public's influence over decision-making. This is not the end of the debate, but rather the beginning of a new era in environmental assessment".
If we take the Minister of the Environment at his word in this matter, we see that these are very strong, caring words about building an environmental assessment process that will, in fact, protect the environment over a long period of time.
March 16, 1992

What the member for Davenport has pointed out to us today is that part of the process of protecting the environment is being delegated to others, perhaps outside of the department, perhaps to anyone. We are being asked to trust the delegation of authority to those out there.
I read into the record the section that we are talking about here, section 17 on page 14:
A responsible authority may delegate to any person, body or jurisdiction within the meaning of subsection 12(5), any part of the screening or comprehensive study of a project or the preparation of the screening report or comprehensive study report, and may delegate any part of the design and implementation of a follow-up program, but shall not delegate the duty to take a course of action pursuant to subsection 20(1) or 37(1).
What the member for Davenport is telling us is that while this is an important part of the process, because we cannot expect the Minister of the Environment to do everything, it is an important part of the process that we have to protect, without giving the minister the opportunity to terminate agreements that have been reached by responsible authorities, then what we are doing is we are allowing on some occasions perhaps an inadequate process to carry on to an end that none of us will find acceptable.
A termination policy must be in place during the course of any of this delegation of authority. It is only the minister who should eventually have the ability to terminate that agreement.
I find it would be a failure on the part of this act not to have that in place.. The amendment before us today sets out very clearly and easily a way to achieve the results that I think we are all looking for.
When the Minister of the Environment says that we are talking about the beginning of a process, a beginning of a debate, we have to recognize that he is understanding and very sympathetic to the ongoing nature of the process that we have begun here.
Another amendment deals with a five year review of the act and gives us an understanding that the government is prepared to acknowledge that there are some failures that we are not quite ready to acknowledge yet because we do not know how everything is going to pan out so to speak.
We have an opportunity right now to correct one of
Government Orders
those deficiencies without waiting for five years to do the review and to put it all into place. This is a very easy way to achieve that. Accepting the member for Davenport's fine amendment at this point is something that is the least that the House can do at this time.

Mr. Speaker, the amendments put forth by the member for Davenport demonstrate not only the value of the committee work that has preceded this debate in the House, but also the depth of talent within this House.
The member for Davenport is a former minister of the environment and he has brought that history to the committee. He has seen where there are little loopholes. As my colleague from Skeena has pointed out, the longer the bill is, the more opportunity there is for loopholes.
The committee work in this House is much misunderstood and yet it is some of the most important work of this House. I know the media is focusing mostly on Question Period and perhaps on debates in the House. But behind the scenes there are some very good people doing some very good work for the people of Canada.
This is just one instance where the member for Davenport, from his experience that he has drawn on by having been a minister of the environment, has put forward these very useful and important amendments.
I hope the government will see fit to support these amendments.

Mr. Speaker, I too would like to rise in support of the amendments of my colleague the hon. member for Davenport.
I would actually like to pick up on the comments that have just been made by the member for Saanich-Gulf Islands both as to the truly effective work that was done by the committee and the way in which the committee came together to substantially improve this bill, much of which is really as a result of the individual skills of the members.
The fact that the member for Davenport is a former member of the cabinet and indeed perhaps that person who more than any other in the political process brought environmental concerns to the forefront of the nation's concerns is indicated in these amendments.

March 16, 1992

The amendments he has brought forth are the fruit of a lengthy experience and it is indeed pretty heart-warming for me as a member of this House to see those opinions expressed here.

speakeroldname: Mr. Lee Clark (Parliamentary Secretary to Minister of the Environment):
speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of the Environment
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, there are two or three points I would like to make in response to other comments made in the House.
First of all, I would like to thank the hon. member for Davenport for his continued practice of speaking very specifically to the issue at hand.
I would also like to make specific comments to Motions Nos. 11 and 18. With respect to Motion No. 11 my hon. friend for The Battlefords-Meadow Lake read clause 17(1) which relates to a minister's power in the process of delegation.
The first thing that must be stressed lest anyone watching perhaps misunderstands is that the responsible authority in the end of course is left with the decisionmaking authority. That is the ultimate power.
Although there is provision in the bill whereby responsible authority may enter into arrangements to delegate part of the screening or comprehensive study, including the preparation of that material to a provincial body or body set up under the lands claims agreement or any other self-governing agreement, what is clear is that the responsible authority in the end is left with the decisionmaking process. I think that is as all of us would wish.
It is also important to note in clause 17(2) because my hon. friend read all of clause 17(1), but in clause 17(2) in the proposed legislation it says "for greater certainty a responsible authority shall not take a course of action pursuant to subsection 20(1), or 37(1) which relates to decision-making power unless it is satisfied that any duty or function delegated pursuant to subsection 1 has been carried out in accordance with this act and the regulations".
In other words what is very clear is the responsible authority, the relevant minister, does indeed have the
power to ensure that any part of the process that has been delegated has been done so in accordance with the act and in accordance with the regulations.
It is for that reason that I would suggest to you that the proposed Motion No. 11 of the hon. member for Davenport is not necessary.
With respect to Motion No. 18 which refers to clause 37(1) in the bill, I would note and perhaps it will be recalled from previous debates, that part of the philosophy in this legislation is indeed the principle of selfassessment. It is an important principle and perhaps it is one which is not fully understood.
Part of the principle of self-assessment is indeed to accept the fact that all those who might have a responsibility pertaining to the environment are required to accept that responsibility. There have been times during the hearings when this was questioned.
The concept of self-assessment is important because it is saying really that one cannot ask any one individual, any one minister, to become in a sense a superpower.
The philosophy indeed is that this is a responsibility which must be shared by all participants, not just by all ministers within the federal government, present or future. What is consistent within the legislation is the realization that it must also be shared by other jurisdictions, and in a sense by way of implication it says by Canadians everywhere. The reason I think this principle is important is that it must be clearly understood that government alone cannot be held accountable for the protection of the environment. It is a responsibility that must go far beyond the Chamber, the cabinet or future cabinets to other jurisdictions, to Canadians everywhere.
I would also note that there is an important aspect of accountability in this process. We must remember that as politicians we are accountable for each and every one of our actions. Clauses 22 and clauses 36 to 38 provide for the publication of reports and the justification for not following the recommendation of those reports.
What is clear is there is a direct line between the decision-making part of government, irrespective of which responsible authority that might be, back to the public at large. I think that line is very important. It is a line which must be maintained.
March 16, 1992

I would also like to make note of the earlier discussion when the hon. member for Skeena, who is present, was referring to the comprehensive list and making reference to the fact that perhaps a nuclear reactor would not be on that comprehensive list. What is important in this legislation is to understand that we are proposing to put into law the methodology by which environmental assessment can occur. We are trying to make it as specific, as well understood, and as all inclusive as we can.
The fact that a particular project is not on a comprehensive list does not of course in any way preclude the fact that that project could indeed be subject to an assessment by an environmental panel, to be referred to a full review, once it has gone through the screening process. We are simply trying to delineate much more clearly now and into the future how that procedure will take place rather than the more loosely drafted guidelines which have been in place since 1984. It was not the intention that they would be law at that point in time; they were designed to be guidelines and were subsequently given the force of law by court decisions.
Here we have what we think is an attempt to clarify and to solidify the environmental assessment process. We believe that indeed we have gone significant steps forward. I would not pretend, as no other member would pretend in this House, that any law passed in the year 1992 is going to necessarily meet the needs of 1994,1996, or whatever the time may be. We truly believe that what we have in our hands today is, as other members have said, a very significant step beyond that which we have had during the course of this administration.
I want it to be understood therefore that the decision as to whether or not a project would be assessed by way of a public panel will be the result of this process unfolding as it does. There is a series of steps in that regard and certainly I think we will discover there is a very significant opportunity for public participation in that process. Certainly, in my mind at least, we will see much more public involvement in the future than we have on occasions in the past.

Mr. Speaker, I rise to support the amendment proposed by my friend from Davenport. Even as members of the public were listen-
Govemment Orders
ing to the parliamentary secretary read clause 17, it became quite clear that the termination wording as proposed by the member for Davenport is precisely required.
Before I get into the specifics of it, Mr. Speaker, I have to tell you a little story. It is always good to have an occasional little story. My friend from Crowfoot likes to hear occasional stories.
I used to live next to one of the most beautiful areas of British Columbia where the Parsnip and the Finley rivers join. A dam by the name of the W. A. C. Bennett Dam was built and flooded it back and created what is known as Williston Lake. My friend who is here, the member from Port Moody, also did some work up in that same area with the Beaver people who lived there, the Sekanni people who were flooded out as that lake was rising. They were flooded out of their home communities and they moved into Ingenika and Fort Weir and some moved on down to Bear Lake and elsewhere.
One of the things that I found interesting that they were confounded by, and it still sticks in my memory to this very day, is that during the wintertime because it is so cold in that area the surface of the lake would freeze hard with three or four feet of ice. During the winter months because of the hydro requirements in big cities like Vancouver the turbines would run all winter long and draw the lake down.
If one were to look out as the Saw people took me out to do, the Beaver people who lived that area, one would see the lake. If one were asked "how deep is the lake", one would see the frozen ice going from one shore to the other of one of the largest lakes in Canada, more than 100 miles long. One would say that it was a very deep lake. If one ever fell through the ice, as some people did in logging trucks and in other circumstances, one would fall farther than from the top of this Chamber to the floor. That would be the depth of the ice, and the whole lake had been drawn down.
The reason I raise this story is to illustrate that what you see, Mr. Speaker, is not always what you get. Looking at it in the wintertime it would look like a nice frozen lake, but if you fell through you would not get your legs in the water while you still held on to the ice.

Government Orders
Bill C-13 is a bit like the ice above the lake. What is really underneath, what is really found in the regulatory powers and so on, is what this bill is all about.
Let us look at what my friend from Davenport is seeking. If we look at clause 17(1), it refers to the delegation of authority and says: "A responsible authority may delegate to any person, body or jurisdiction within the meaning-any part of the screening or comprehensive study of a project or the preparation of a screening report or comprehensive study report", and on it goes. The authority can be delegated.
Then it says, as my friend the parliamentary secretary read: "For greater certainty, a responsible authority shall not take a course of action pursuant to these other subsections unless it is satisfied that any duty or function delegated pursuant to section 1 has been carried out in accordance with this act and the regulations".
We would never know that. Clearly there should be another clause to allow for termination. Let me give another example.
A friend of mine who teaches law in British Columbia was working at the University of Victoria law school. The Minister of the Environment allowed him to go in and do a computer search of what are known as class 1 and class 2 permits which allow for pollution of water, air or land, mostly pulp mills and large industries. He went through all the computer base and Canada, this Parliament, had passed over or delegated to the province of British Columbia under the Fisheries Act the right to administer the permitting structures in relation to those class 1 and class 2 permits to place effluents into water. Of course there are fish in the water.
Therefore it is a federal power very clearly understood constitutionally in this country. What he found was shocking and it still shocks me to this day. He found 75 per cent significant, non-compliance for more than a year of the permits that had been delegated from Canada to the province. The province had its environment people out there but in three-quarters of the cases there was significant non-compliance for more than a year.
My friend from Davenport is seeking what one would intelligently expect in a large federation such as ours with two huge territories and 10 provinces and without
the kinds of enforceable national standards that would be required for the assessments of policy, projects large and small, comprehensive studies, and so on. Without that in place he is simply asking for an intelligent safety mechanism where a minister comes to be apprised that a delegated authority is either incompetent for a variety of reasons, perhaps not even intentionally, and comes to find himself or herself or the corporate entity to be incompetent to complete a study, to complete an assessment or whatever.
Basically what the House has to recognize during this debate is that clause 17 is simply inadequate. It does not provide the minister with the kind of authority he or she simply requires in order to be able to have either a review panel or a mitigation process properly carried out.
Again I dip into my bank of documents stamped "Secret, for minister's eyes only". It is often in these kinds of documents that one will find the tacky track record of the senior bureaucracy at the political level and what it was thinking about while this material was being prepared. I quote from "Secret, FEARO" page 3, section 10: "Mandatory procedures including public review established by the proposed legislation will apply only to projects as the case may dictate. Ministers will have an obligation to assess new policy proposals but procedures will be discretionary. Public review of policy proposals would be at the discretion of the responsible minister".
We sort of learn as we go along. We can look at Oldman. We know in the case of Oldman that the Minister of Transport is still not even living up to the direction of the Supreme Court of Canada. He was found to have an affirmative, regulatory duty. Has the Minister of Transport lived up to an affirmative, regulatory duty? Every member of this House knows what that is. Every member of this House has a copy of the Navigable Waters Act and we all know the Minister of Transport is not living up to it for political reasons.
What should be done is that the reservoir should not be filled any further. When we look at this legislation we are looking particularly at the proposed additional clause of the member for Davenport. I see you nodding, Mr. Speaker. You are in agreement now, after this vigorous and not overly protracted debate, that this is the kind of thing that should be included. I see we are able to
March 16, 1992

persuade the parliamentary secretary now. Perhaps, if the minister were not at Globe 92, he would rise now before Question Period and agree that this is the kind of clause that should be included.
I think it has been a fairly successful debate this morning. I would just like to close off, Mr. Speaker. You have had a moment to reflect on my story about the level of the ice and the real level of Bill C-13. We have an opportunity, this being the springtime, to fill it back up again with goodwill on behalf of Canada's environment.

Mr. Speaker, the member for Skeena, our environment critic, spoke eloquently on this amendment to clause 17. The amendment is in the name of my friend from Davenport who is a former environment minister and whose amendments and remarks are always worth considering and are usually persuasive in this House. I rise to speak on that.
The hon. member for Skeena mentioned the notion of Williston Lake. I happened to be with him one time going up that lake. It is really quite startling. It is a 100-mile long lake that was created by us, really, by engineers and so on. They created that lake and that caused some very strange things to happen.
The member mentioned what it was like in winter and the illusion of the ice, the illusion of normality. One should see it in summer. There used to be some beautiful native villages and a beautiful valley there.
It was decided that we needed this power. There was no environmental assessment, nothing. There was a dam. The Bennett dam was built there. In the summer you cannot go along that lake in a canoe because, if you do, you are liable to get a missile hitting you from the bottom. The trees at the bottom were left there when it was flooded. Over time they have become loose. As you go along, occasionally the trees will just come up like a guided missile from the bottom and surface on the lake. People have actually been hurt in boats and canoes. They cannot go on the lake.
It is important that we now get a modem environmental process that really works. That is why the minister's discretion must be looked at very carefully. As the member for Skeena said, there must be enforceable national standards. We must not set up an act in which a weak minister or a weak government like this Conservative government can start ignoring things to help their
friends as they did with the Oldman Dam in Saskatchewan.
I know we are going into Question Period, so we will come back to this amendment. I hope the House can support this amendment so that we can make a strong, enforceable standard here.

It was argued that hysteria was tolerated and encouraged by the male dominated medical profession as an outlet for women's frustrations because such expressions of discontent did not have the power to effect socioeconomic and political change.

Madam Speaker, this past weekend's constitutional conference highlights a week of tremendous advancement for aboriginal peoples in Canada, beginning with a Special Joint Committee on a Renewed Canada recommending the entrenchment of an inherent right to self-government, this Chamber's recognition of Louis Riel's contribution to Confederation and leaders of the four national aboriginal organizations being invited to become full participants in the constitutional process of the Canada round.
Yesterday, the sixth conference of First Peoples and the Constitution concluded on a very positive note under the excellent leadership of co-chairs Premier Joe Ghiz and ICC President Mary Simon.
Issues on the inherent right to self-government, jurisdiction and responsibility, implementation and the First Peoples' recognition were deliberated with enthusiasm.

speakeroldname: Hon. John C. Crosbie (Minister of Fisheries and Oceans and Minister for the Atlantic Canada Opportunities Agency):

speechtext:
(a) DFO initiated an environmental screening of Cominco Mineral Limited's use of hover-
March 16, 1992

craft to transport materials between Bronson Creek on the Iskut River and Wrangell, Alaska, which was originally completed in February, 1991.
The screening report concluded that some of the potentially adverse effects of the hovercraft operations were unknown, and thus the project fell within section 12(d) of the Environmental Assessment and Review Process (EARP) guidelines order. The report recommended that Cominco prepare a contingency plan for prevention, containment and clean-up of spilled fuel and hazardous products, as well as collect additional information to assess the effects of hovercraft operation on fish and wildlife. The project was permitted to proceed on this basis and was to employ a "thalweg" approach to navigation, i.e. keeping to main channels, that avoids fish spawning and rearing areas and commercial fishing operations on the Iskut and Stikine Rivers.
In June 1991, the EARP screening report was revised to incorporate further information regarding the effects of hovercraft operation on fish and wildlife. No evidence was found to indicate that noise generated by hovercraft would be harmful to any life stage of salmon, and keeping hovercraft operation to the main channels of the rivers would minimize disturbance to salmon and other wildlife species. The screening decision was revised to 12(c) after DFO concluded that potentially adverse effects could be mitigated with existing technology.
In response to public concerns, the impact of wake generated by hovercraft operations on the river shoreline was investigated. An inspection of hovercraft operation was made on October 24, 1991. The wave produced by the hovercraft was estimated to be 0.15 metres in height, comparable to waves generated by typical river-boats of much smaller size. The Stikine and Iskut Rivers are very large and dynamic systems, subject to extremely high spring and summer flows and icing during the winter. Erosion is a constant occurrence during widely fluctuating water levels and velocity regimes; thus, disturbances caused by minor boat wake are not significant when compared to the magnitude of natural occurrences.

speechtext: The hon. member for Port Moody-Coquitlam, welcome back.

Madam Speaker, I want to thank you for your generosity to me now and in Question Period this afternoon. I do appreciate that.
I will just conclude. I tried to ask a short question, I point out, in return. I just wanted to conclude my remarks.
We are speaking on this very important environmental bill. The House has heard a number of speeches this morning. It has heard from the member for Skeena, the member for The Battlefords-Meadow Lake who worked so hard on this committee, and the member for Saanich-Gulf Islands who worked so hard on environmental issues.
You will recall I presented a petition in the House a few minutes ago. I was just out getting a photocopy of that because it reflected, in a sense, what I was saying in
March 16, 1992

my first speech, that young people are really concerned about the environment. This was on a broader environmental issue. The petition, as you will recall, was from the students at Sir Frederick Banting Junior Secondary School in Coquitlam. Those students were concerned about a loophole.
It is very technical. You really have to know what you are talking about to get into this issue. The students really got into it. They found a loophole in the international whaling commission moratorium on commercial whaling. They found that you could in fact kill whales for scientific research purposes. Under the guise of science, you can butcher a number of whales and you can supposedly conduct the research. You then send the whales to the marketplace and sell them. What happens then is that countries like Iceland, Norway and Japan which were trying to observe the whaling moratorium then say: "Well, we had better get back into a full scale commercial whaling because it has been going on anyway".
I cite the petition of the students from Banting Junior Secondary School for two reasons. One of the reasons is the sophistication of the young people dealing with a major international environmental issue in a complicated way. Second, as the member for Skeena was saying, it shows once again that what you see is sometimes not exactly what exists, in this case sort of looking at a way of killing whales for scientific research when in fact they are still trying to look at money in the market. That is why we have to be so careful with this particular bill.
I was just looking at the press release that was put out on this bill by my party where the hon. member had outlined a number of points. There were a number of points that we put forward to try and amend this bill. There were 111 amendments introduced during the committee's review of the legislation. Some of them were accepted. We, in the New Democratic Party, managed to change the bill by including some of the changes.
First, forcing the government to assess alternatives to major projects affecting federal jurisdiction and requiring that the need for a project in the first place be determined before it goes ahead.
Second, drastically reducing government discretion- that is why this amendment is important here-in
Government Orders
deciding what projects are assessed, how they are assessed and what factors have to be taken into account during the assessment and whether a project should go ahead.
Third, requiring a review of this bill after five years.
Fourth, improving public participation, strengthening support for sustainable development, increasing the protection of aboriginal rights and including physical and cultural heritage in the definition of the environment.
It is very important having these items to strengthen the bill. We must go farther in this debate in the House and seriously consider the amendment that has just been presented by the hon. member for Davenport. As I understand it, it is an amendment that will protect us from a minister who is not particularly sympathetic or weak, present company excepted, who will be lobbied by a large corporation or by some other interest and will back off and delegate his or her power to some other group. That is why this has to be very tightly controlled.
While I am on my feet, I also want to make reference to something that the hon. member for The Battle-fords-Meadow Lake said. He said that the environment in his riding is truly beautiful. He mentioned Meadow Lake and a summer picnic I had the privilege of attending with him.
You were the guest speaker.

My friend says I was the guest speaker. Well it became less nice after that. The hon. member said he had been to India after that and stated how difficult it was to find a pristine lake in India.
One great British Columbian, former Justice Tom Berger, I want to inform the House, is in India doing the first of its kind, an international impact study sponsored by the World Bank dealing with the Saravar Dam in India on the Narmada River. That is very interesting because 15 years ago or so, Justice Berger did the first environmental assessment of a great megaproject, the proposed Mackenzie Valley natural gas pipeline from Alaska and the Mackenzie delta down to southern Canada and the United States. This was the first of its kind in the world. It was the first real look at a project before the project was built. That is where we learned a lot of matters that are in this bill. We learned how to

March 16, 1992
Government Orders
really do an environmental assessment. We learned how to conduct public hearings. We learned how to fund interveners and what an advantage, not a disadvantage, that was to governments and the process to have all broad points of view.
Let me conclude by saying that we have done great things in the world on the environment. We are pioneering. We have a bill to which we in this party, who are committed to the environment, proposed 111 amendments. There is another amendment on the floor which we think will strengthen the bill. We ask the government and the House to support this amendment.
Remember what the students of Sir Frederick Banting Junior Secondary School said, that the environment is the key issue in the modem world.

Madam Speaker, my remarks will be very brief. I want to compliment the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of the Environment and all committee members on this work.
I would like to put forward to members that there is confusion from time to time in the overlapping jurisdictions. I want to bring this down to my own community in Toronto where we have three rivers that flow through the centre of our city; the Don River, the Rouge River and the Humber River. They flow into Lake Ontario which is a lake that we share with the United States. These are the most polluted rivers in all of Canada.
For years we have had the toxic and biological waste from the largest city in Canada flowing down these rivers into Lake Ontario. They are now just chemical cauldrons.
It seems that because of the overlapping jurisdictions from the municipality to the province, to the conservation boards and ultimately, because of the Great Lakes, the federal jurisdiction, there is always the pointing of fingers at each other, that the municipality is responsible for a certain facet and then ultimately the province. We do report after report but there is never, ever a real final
action plan or the resources to begin reclaiming these rivers.
I hope that as we go through the various phases of this bill that we can somehow give the national government a clear cut responsibility for acting when we have overlapping jurisdictions on a particular environmental disaster. Yet there does not seem to be the will of those like the province, those bodies responsible to take action.
I cite another example from two years ago in Barrier Lake, just three hours north of us, where it was obvious the clear-cutting that was done in that area was beyond the sustainable development definition. The Algonguins of Barrier Lake could not get the support of the province to stop the clear-cutting. It was a clear cut case where the province should have stepped in and stopped it.
Yet, we as a national government, other than moral suasion, were not really in a position to do anything about it. We have a similar situation in Alberta with the pulp and paper mills going into the Athabasca River region.
My concern is that there should be some clear definition so that the national government can step in and put a much more aggressive position forward, the ultimate position when the operating authorities fail to act.
I hope in committee that specific examples like that can be addressed. Quite frankly, if there is one frustration I face it is that every month I get approached from constituents in my riding asking: "What specific action is taking place on the clean-up of the Don River? What is the national government doing about it?" You turn around and say: "It is the province that is supposed to be doing something about it". The province says: "It is the municipality". We, as a national government, seem to have either relinquished or do not have that final thrust.
I hope that we can have a clear-cut definition of our responsibility by the time we bring this bill to its final resting place.

Madam Speaker, I would just like to reinforce to the committee what the hon. member for Broadview-Greenwood has just said. I have the same problem in my riding of Parkdale- High Park.
Every summer, when the temperatures reach 80 and 90 degrees, the beaches on Lake Ontario are closed all along Mississauga, Toronto, et cetera. Just when the
March 16, 1992

children want to jump into the lake and swim, the beaches are closed. When you try to get to the bottom of the cause of these pollutants again you get this buck passing; municipalities looking to the province for solutions, the province looking to the federal government and vice versa.
Forty years ago, when I came to Ontario, the joy that we had was to be able to swim in Lake Ontario. Now, 40 years later, we cannot swim in the same lake that we swam 40 years ago. Because Lake Ontario joins the Great Lakes, there is international involvement here so the federal government has to be involved. Pollutants do come down the Humber River to the mouth of the Humber so the province is involved.
Canada geese do a lot of polluting. Everyone is powerless to even reduce the number of Canada geese on the beaches when the rain washes their waste into Lake Ontario.
I am glad that the hon. member for Broadview- Greenwood gave that direction to the committee. I would also like to emphasize that because it is very very important. In my area, it is four levels of government. It is the federal government, the provincial government, the metropolitan Toronto government and the city of Toronto. There are four jurisdictions there and four jurisdictions cannot solve this little problem of keeping the beaches open for the children when the temperatures reach 80 and 90 degrees in July and August. Something is wrong with us, the politicians, if we cannot get four levels of government together to clean up the beaches for our children every summer.
